text: The product of the B-cell - specific <extra_id_0> B29 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene ( <extra_id_0> B29 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> Ig beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> CD79b <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is essential for Ig - mediated B-cell activation via the B-cell antigen receptor complex ( BCR ) on human and murine B lymphocytes .

To better understand the regulation of this pivotal gene , we have analyzed the human genomic DNA sequence upstream of the <extra_id_0> B29 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ATG start codon for transcriptional control activity .
The human <extra_id_0> B29 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene lacks either a TATA or a CAAT box and transcription is initiated at multiple sites .
The minimal promoter of the human <extra_id_0> B29 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene is contained within a 193-bp region 5 ' of these multiple start sites .
This minimal promoter exhibits B-cell - specific activity and contains SP1 , ETS , OCT , and IKAROS / LYF-1 transcription factor motifs .
All these motifs are strikingly conserved in sequence and placement relative to the previously characterized murine <extra_id_0> B29 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter .
Additional upstream gene segments dramatically affected <extra_id_0> B29 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> minimal promoter activity .

A newly identified motif called the <extra_id_0> B29 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> conserved sequence ( BCS ) , found upstream of both human and murine <extra_id_0> B29 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoters , appears to stimulate <extra_id_0> B29 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcription through a novel mechanism .

text: A single BCS had little effect either on the minimal <extra_id_0> B29 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter or on a heterologous promoter .

Instead , the BCS stimulated transcription by counteracting 5 ' negative regulatory DNA sequences that block the activity of the <extra_id_0> B29 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> minimal promoter in its absence .
These findings indicate that <extra_id_0> B29 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene expression is controlled by the complex interplay of positive and negative regulatory elements .
